trans-unit.source: Develop Java MapReduce programs for Hadoop | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Develop Java MapReduce programs for Hadoop | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to develop Java MapReduce programs on HDInsight emulator, how to deploy them to HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to develop Java MapReduce programs on HDInsight emulator, how to deploy them to HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: Develop Java MapReduce programs for Hadoop in HDInsight
trans-unit.target: Develop Java MapReduce programs for Hadoop in HDInsight

trans-unit.source: This documents walks you through using Apache Maven to create a MapReduce application, then deploy and run it on a Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: This documents walks you through using Apache Maven to create a MapReduce application, then deploy and run it on a Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Java JDK</linkText><title></title></link> 7 or later (or an equivalent, such as OpenJDK)
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Java JDK</linkText><title></title></link> 7 or later (or an equivalent, such as OpenJDK)

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Apache Maven</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Apache Maven</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription: See Get Azure free trial.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription: See Get Azure free trial.

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI: For more information, see Install and configure Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI: For more information, see Install and configure Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Configure environment variables
trans-unit.target: Configure environment variables

trans-unit.source: The following environment variables may be set when you install Java and the JDK.
trans-unit.target: The following environment variables may be set when you install Java and the JDK.

trans-unit.source: However, you should check that they exist and that they contain the correct values for your system.
trans-unit.target: However, you should check that they exist and that they contain the correct values for your system.

trans-unit.source: JAVA_HOME - should point to the directory where the Java runtime environment (JRE) is installed.
trans-unit.target: JAVA_HOME - should point to the directory where the Java runtime environment (JRE) is installed.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a OS X, Unix or Linux system, it should have a value similar to /usr/lib/jvm/java-7-oracle.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a OS X, Unix or Linux system, it should have a value similar to /usr/lib/jvm/java-7-oracle.

trans-unit.source: In Windows, it would have a value similar to c:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre1.7
trans-unit.target: In Windows, it would have a value similar to c:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre1.7

trans-unit.source: PATH - should contain the following paths:
trans-unit.target: PATH - should contain the following paths:

trans-unit.source: JAVA_HOME (or the equivalent path)
trans-unit.target: JAVA_HOME (or the equivalent path)

trans-unit.source: JAVA_HOME\bin (or the equivalent path)
trans-unit.target: JAVA_HOME\bin (or the equivalent path)

trans-unit.source: The directory where Maven is installed
trans-unit.target: The directory where Maven is installed

trans-unit.source: Create a new Maven project
trans-unit.target: Create a new Maven project

trans-unit.source: From a terminal session, or command line in your development environment, change directories to the location you want to store this project.
trans-unit.target: From a terminal session, or command line in your development environment, change directories to the location you want to store this project.

trans-unit.source: Use the mvn command, which is installed with Maven, to generate the scaffolding for the project.
trans-unit.target: Use the mvn command, which is installed with Maven, to generate the scaffolding for the project.

trans-unit.source: This will create a new directory in the current directory, with the name specified by the artifactID parameter (wordcountjava in this example.)
trans-unit.target: This will create a new directory in the current directory, with the name specified by the artifactID parameter (wordcountjava in this example.)

trans-unit.source: This directory will contain the following items:
trans-unit.target: This directory will contain the following items:

trans-unit.source: pom.xml - The Project Object Model (POM) that contains information and configuration details used to build the project.
trans-unit.target: pom.xml - The Project Object Model (POM) that contains information and configuration details used to build the project.

trans-unit.source: src - The directory that contains the main/java/org/apache/hadoop/examples directory, where you will author the application.
trans-unit.target: src - The directory that contains the main/java/org/apache/hadoop/examples directory, where you will author the application.

trans-unit.source: Delete the src/test/java/org/apache/hadoop/examples/apptest.java file, as it will not be used in this example.
trans-unit.target: Delete the src/test/java/org/apache/hadoop/examples/apptest.java file, as it will not be used in this example.

trans-unit.source: Add dependencies
trans-unit.target: Add dependencies

trans-unit.source: Edit the pom.xml file and add the following inside the section:
trans-unit.target: Edit the pom.xml file and add the following inside the section:

trans-unit.source: This tells Maven that the project requires the libraries (listed within <html></html>) with a specific version (listed within <html></html>). At compile time, this will be downloaded from the default Maven repository. You can use the <link><linkText>Maven repository search</linkText><title></title></link> to view more.
trans-unit.target: This tells Maven that the project requires the libraries (listed within <html></html>) with a specific version (listed within <html></html>). At compile time, this will be downloaded from the default Maven repository. You can use the <link><linkText>Maven repository search</linkText><title></title></link> to view more.

trans-unit.source: The provided tells Maven that these dependencies should not be packaged with the application, as they will be provided by the HDInsight cluster at run-time.
trans-unit.target: The provided tells Maven that these dependencies should not be packaged with the application, as they will be provided by the HDInsight cluster at run-time.

trans-unit.source: Add the following to the pom.xml file. This must be inside the ... tags in the file; for example, between and .
trans-unit.target: Add the following to the pom.xml file. This must be inside the ... tags in the file; for example, between and .

trans-unit.source: The first plugin configures the <link><linkText>Maven Shade Plugin</linkText><title></title></link>, which is used to build an uberjar (sometimes called a fatjar), which contains dependencies required by the application.
trans-unit.target: The first plugin configures the <link><linkText>Maven Shade Plugin</linkText><title></title></link>, which is used to build an uberjar (sometimes called a fatjar), which contains dependencies required by the application.

trans-unit.source: It also prevents duplication of licenses within the jar package, which can cause problems on some systems.
trans-unit.target: It also prevents duplication of licenses within the jar package, which can cause problems on some systems.

trans-unit.source: The second plugin configures the Maven compiler, which is used to set the version of Java required by this application to the version used on the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: The second plugin configures the Maven compiler, which is used to set the version of Java required by this application to the version used on the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Save the pom.xml file.
trans-unit.target: Save the pom.xml file.

trans-unit.source: Create the MapReduce application
trans-unit.target: Create the MapReduce application

trans-unit.source: Go to the wordcountjava/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/examples directory and rename the App.java file to WordCount.java.
trans-unit.target: Go to the wordcountjava/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/examples directory and rename the App.java file to WordCount.java.

trans-unit.source: Open the WordCount.java file in a text editor and replace the contents with the following:
trans-unit.target: Open the WordCount.java file in a text editor and replace the contents with the following:

trans-unit.source: Notice the package name is org.apache.hadoop.examples and the class name is WordCount.
trans-unit.target: Notice the package name is org.apache.hadoop.examples and the class name is WordCount.

trans-unit.source: You will use these names when you submit the MapReduce job.
trans-unit.target: You will use these names when you submit the MapReduce job.

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: Build the application
trans-unit.target: Build the application

trans-unit.source: Change to the wordcountjava directory, if you are not already there.
trans-unit.target: Change to the wordcountjava directory, if you are not already there.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to build a JAR file containing the application:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to build a JAR file containing the application:

trans-unit.source: This will clean any previous build artifacts, download any dependencies that have not already been installed, and then build and package the application.
trans-unit.target: This will clean any previous build artifacts, download any dependencies that have not already been installed, and then build and package the application.

trans-unit.source: Once the command finishes, the wordcountjava/target directory will contain a file named wordcountjava-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar.
trans-unit.target: Once the command finishes, the wordcountjava/target directory will contain a file named wordcountjava-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar.

trans-unit.source: The wordcountjava-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar file is an uberjar, which contains not only the WordCount job, but also dependencies that the job requires at runtime.
trans-unit.target: The wordcountjava-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar file is an uberjar, which contains not only the WordCount job, but also dependencies that the job requires at runtime.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Upload the jar
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Upload the jar

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to upload the jar file to the HDInsight headnode:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to upload the jar file to the HDInsight headnode:

trans-unit.source: This copies the files from the local system to the head node.
trans-unit.target: This copies the files from the local system to the head node.

trans-unit.source: If you used a password to secure your SSH account, you will be prompted for the password.
trans-unit.target: If you used a password to secure your SSH account, you will be prompted for the password.

trans-unit.source: If you used an SSH key, you may have to use the -i parameter and the path to the private key.
trans-unit.target: If you used an SSH key, you may have to use the -i parameter and the path to the private key.

trans-unit.source: For example, scp -i /path/to/private/key wordcountjava-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar USERNAME@CLUSTERNAME-ssh.azurehdinsight.net:.
trans-unit.target: For example, scp -i /path/to/private/key wordcountjava-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar USERNAME@CLUSTERNAME-ssh.azurehdinsight.net:.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Run the MapReduce job
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Run the MapReduce job

trans-unit.source: Connect to HDInsight using SSH as described in the following articles:
trans-unit.target: Connect to HDInsight using SSH as described in the following articles:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Linux, Unix, or OS X</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Use SSH with Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight from Windows</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: From the SSH session, use the following command to run the MapReduce application:
trans-unit.target: From the SSH session, use the following command to run the MapReduce application:

trans-unit.source: This will use the WordCount MapReduce application to count the words in the davinci.txt file, and store the results to wasb:///example/data/wordcountout.
trans-unit.target: This will use the WordCount MapReduce application to count the words in the davinci.txt file, and store the results to wasb:///example/data/wordcountout.

trans-unit.source: Both the input file and output are stored to the default storage for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Both the input file and output are stored to the default storage for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Once the job completes, use the following to view the results:
trans-unit.target: Once the job completes, use the following to view the results:

trans-unit.source: You should receive a list of words and counts, with values similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should receive a list of words and counts, with values similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Next steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Next steps

trans-unit.source: In this document, you have learned how to develop a Java MapReduce job.
trans-unit.target: In this document, you have learned how to develop a Java MapReduce job.

trans-unit.target: See the following documents for other ways to work with HDInsight.
